text: thinking about things some more, I am not sure that the class of events generated by chaincode can _not_ be part of the block somehow
I agree things like txn/block status are peer local and in no way belong in the persistence layer
but, for chaincode events, it seems that not including them in the block leaves the system ripe for excluding all except the voting endorsers to know about the event
but perhaps there is a better solution?
I actually am ok if only endorsers are capable of detecting/disseminating events, as that seems like the right scope from a privilege perspecptive
(IOW, i am not worried about non-endoring validators missing the signal to transmit the event)

but, say I had 10 endorsers but only 7 were involved in actively endorsing a transaction because the other three were slower, would someone subscribed to one of the slow endorsers just not find out about the event?
it seems like if, minimally hash([S’ E]) were on the block, then a slow node could use something like state transfer to recover E and send it as it learns about a committed block
is there another way that doesnt involve block state?
to put it another way, it seems like “E” is very much akin to “just another output” of the process
I am not sure that audit-ability of E is important, but having the messages have a semblance of reliability is probably important
there might be other ways to achieve that
I personally think E should be treated with the same confidentiality scope as S, which is why I am fine with subscriptions only working within the set of VPs that are endorsers for the event source
<@U0ULK2JPP>: <@U0MT4CBHB> thoughts?
yes. It was one of the reasons I opposed persistent E as it will potentially leak privacy if not handled the same as S
I agree it should be scoped identically
scoped/handled identically
e.g. if S is encrypted, E is encrypted the same, etc
at least w.r.t. the block data
the event itself probably wouldnt be encrypted or at least, not in the same way…just as a query response wouldnt be encrypted per se
we could think of events as special variant of  query, actually
